Abstract: In the middle 1960's the Government of Guyana embarked on a development program. Selected for early attention was the rice industry -- farm to market. Feasibility studies confirmed the opportunity for successful development in the rice industry. As a result of those findings, the Government of Guyana and USAID negotiated AID Loan in an amount of U.S.$12,900,000 to be supplemented by the GOG in an amount of Guyana dollars equivalent to U.S. $4,600,000. A component of that loan agreement was U.S. $550,000 supplemented by Guyana dollars furnished by the GOG in an amount equal to U.S. $144,000 for technical and managerial assistance. The principle infrastructure to be added by implementation of the loan agreement is a Rice Research Center, six Dryer-Storage Centers, and transportation equipment for bulk paddy and milled rice. The rice research center construction has been started. It is currently scheduled to be completed in December 1974. The six Dryer-Storage Centers, having a capacity to handle and store about 25% of the projected annual crop, and 50% of the projected crop in their areas are under construction. Two are expected to be completed for beneficial occupancy in time for the fall crop 1973; two others may be completed by that time. All six should be beneficially occupied by the fall crop 1974, or before.

Title: Technical and managerial assistance recommendations : rice modernization project, Guyana

Abstract: AN EVALUATION OF THE FIRST FOUR YEARS OF EL SALVADOR'S EDUCATIONAL REFORM AND INSTRUCTIONAL TELEVISION (ITV) SYSTEM. THE THREE OBJECTIVES OF THE EVALUATION WERE: 1) TO STUDY THE EFFECTS OF ITV ON EL SALVADOR'S SCHOOL SYSTEM; 2) MAKE GENERAL CONCLUSIONS FROM THE SYSTEM THAT MIGHT BE HELPFUL TO OTHER COUNTRIES INTERESTED IN INSTRUCTIONAL TECHNOLOGY; AND 3) TO MAKE A CONTRIBUTION THROUGH THIS EVALUATION TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE ITV SYSTEM ITSELF. DATA FOR THE FOUR-YEAR STUDY WILL BE DRAWN FROM THE GENERAL SETTING; STUDENT LEARNING; ATTITUDES, AND ASPIRATIONS; COMMUNITY AND CLASSROOM INFLUENCES ON STUDENTS; TEACHER ATTITUDES AND BEHAVIOR; EFFICIENCY AND COSTS OF THE NEW SYSTEM; ADMINISTRATIVE HISTORY; AND PREDICTIONS FOR THE FUTURE. AMONG THE CONCLUSIONS OF THIS STUDY WERE THAT: 1) BECAUSE OF ITV, STUDENTS LEARNED MORE EVEN WITH GREAT ENROLLMENT EXPANSION; 2) ALTHOUGH EXPENSIVE, ITV WAS LESS SO THAN TRADITIONAL METHODS WOULD HAVE BEEN WITH THIS INCREASE; 3) ITV MAGNIFIED THE NEED FOR CHANGE IN NUMEROUS OTHER EDUCATIONAL AREAS; AND 4) ITV HAS A BRIGHT FUTURE IN EL SALVADOR.

Abstract: THE NATIONAL ACADEMY OF SCIENCES (NAS) APPLIES SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE TO PROBLEMS ASSOCIATED WITH UNDERDEVELOPED COUNTRIES. DURING A TEN-YEAR PERIOD ENDING IN 1971, A CONCENTRATED ATTEMPT WAS MADE BY THE NAS TO DEVELOP PROGRAMS IN AFRICA, ASIA, AND LATIN AMERICA. THESE PROGRAMS ARE REVIEWED AND ANALYZED IN THIS REPORT; THE MAJOR FOCUS IS ON ACTIVITIES RESULTING FROM WORKSHOPS THAT BEGAN IN 1964. REGIONAL ACTIVITIES WERE MULTINATIONAL EFFORTS THAT INCLUDED SOLVING COMMON PROBLEMS OF AGRICULTURE, HEALTH, AND HIGHER EDUCATION IN THE SCIENCES. BILATERAL PROGRAMS FOCUSED ON NATIONAL PRIORITIES, E.G., OCEAN RESOURCES IN INDONESIA. THE NAS WORKSHOPS BROUGHT TOGETHER PEOPLE OF VARIOUS REPRESENTATIONS TO MATCH AND COMPLEMENT EXPERTISE; COLLABORATION CENTERED ON FOUR MAIN TOPICS: MANPOWER AND EDUCATION, AGRICULTURE, NATURAL RESOURCES, AND INDUSTRIAL R & D AND MANAGEMENT. MOST WORKSHOPS EMPHASIZED THE PRIORITIES OF RESEARCH. INCLUDED IN THE REPORT ARE ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS GIVEN EACH COUNTRY ON THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THESE WORKSHOPS. THE PROGRAMS THEMSELVES ARE EVALUATED ACCORDING TO INSTITUTIONAL RELATIONSHIPS (WHERE THE NAS SEES ITS USEFULNESS IN ITS CATALYTIC ROLE) AND SHORT- AND LONG-TERM DEVELOPMENTS. FACTORS CONTRIBUTING TO THE ACCOMPLISHMENTS OF THE BILATERAL PROGRAMS ARE DETAILED. THE REPORT DESCRIBES THESE PROGRAMS (1964-1971), DESCRIBES SPECIAL PROJECTS FROM 1968-1972, AND LISTS STAFF AND INTERNATIONAL PARTICIPANTS FOR EACH PROGRAM.

Abstract: USDA ECON RESEARCH SERVICE-CONTRACTED SPECIAL FEASIBILITY STUDY OF AID-SUPPORTED FY1970-73 WEST AFRICAN REGIONAL POULTRY PROJECT WITH SENEGAL,MALI & MAURITANIA,MEMBERS OF ORGANISATION POUR LA MISE EN VALUER DU FLEUVE SENEGAL  (OMVS) REGIONAL ORGANIZATION. PROJECT SEEKS TO FOSTER DEVELOPMENT OF BROILER PRODUCTION INDUSTRY TO PROVIDE LOW-PRICED POULTRY MEAT/EGGSFOR OMVS CITIZENS. USDA/USAID EVALUATION TEAM REVIEWED PROJ ECT FILES,CONSULTED PROJECT PRINCIPALS & CONDUCTED INTERPRETER-ASSISTED INTERVIEWS WITH SAMPLE OF 102 POULTRY-RELATED ESTABLISHMENTS IN ALL 3 COUNTRIES IN 4-MONTH INTENSIVE EVALUATION. EVALUATORS ASSESSED PROJECT OPERATIONS IN EACH COUNTRY & PROJECT AS A WHOLE. NO ASSESSMENT MADE OF TUSKEGEE INSTITUTE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PROJECT. USDA CONSULTANTS RECOMMEND PRECIPITOUS TERMINATION OF REGIONAL PROJECT DUE TO SERIOUS MANAGEMENT PROBLEMS, INEFFICIENCIES,UNDERDEVELOPED FACILITIES & NON-COMPLIANCE OF HOST GOVERNMENTS WITH PREVIOUS USAID OPERATING RECOMMENDATIONS. EVALUATORS NOTE EFFECT OF SEVERE PERENNIAL DROUGHT & ENSUING PRIORITY USAGE OF AVAILABLE FEED GRAINS FOR HUMAN CONSUMPTION,BUT DO NOT EMPHASIZE SUCH AS RATIONALE FOR UNDEVELOPED OPERATIONS/UNFULFILLED OBJECTIVES. EVEN WITH SUBSIDIZATION,POULTRY MEAT/EGGS FROM OMVS CENTERS REMAIN NON-COMPETITIVE LUXURY COMMODITIES. EVALUATORS RECOMMEND ECONOMIES OF SCALE PRODUCTION & EMPHASIS ON MARKETING TO INCREASE BROILER/EGG DEMAND & LOWER SELLING PRICES. USDA CONSULTANTS NOTE GREATER SUCCESS OF SELECT INDEPENDENT COMMERCIAL PRODUCERS; SUGGEST THEY MIGHT BETTER PROVIDE DEMONSTRATION MODEL. SPECIFIC PROBLEMS OBSERVED INCLUDE INEFFICIENCY OF HAND FEED-MIXING (AUTOMATED FEED-MIXERS NOT YET OPEATIONAL  AT MALI CENTER;LACK OF ELECTRICITY PERSISTS AT MAURITAINIAN CENTER);INADEQUATE SECURITY MGMT FOR DISEASE PREVENTION (70% MORTALITY RATE AT MALI CENTER);PROBLEMS IN COST ACCOUNTING PROCEDURES/PROGRAMMING;AND LACK OF FORWARD PLANNING TO FACILITATE MORE EFFECTIVE COORDINATION OF CHICK PURCHASE/FEED SUPPLIES. PROJECT TRAINING COMPONENTS AS OF YET NOT INITIATED. TEAM RECOMMENDS PROJECT TERMINATION WITH SUBSEQUENT USAID TECHNICAL GUIDANCE ONLY UPON OMVS REQUEST.

Title: ECONOMIC FEASIBILITY OF THE WEST AFRICAN REGIONAL POULTRY PROJECT (MAY 18-SEPT 18, 1973)

Abstract: 1/71-12/73, CHAD, CAMEROON, CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC (CAR). UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH (U OF PITT) CONTRACT TO ADVISE AND ASSIST OCEAC AND COOPERATING COUNTRIES IN DEVELOPING "A BLUEPRINT FOR LOCAL HEALTH SERVICES" WAS ONLY MARGINALLY SUCCESSFUL. ORIGINAL GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF PROJECT WERE JUDGED BY EVALUATORS TO BE UNREALISTIC. THESE WERE ALTERED BY MULTIPLE REVISIONS (IN SOME CASES,WIITHOUT THE FULL KNOWLEDGE OF ALL INVOLVED PARTIES), AND TO DATE, NO COMMON UNDERSTANDING OF THE PROJECT'S INTENT EXISTS. IN BOTH CAR AND CHAD, THE PROJECT HAS EVOLVED AS THE HEALTH EDUCATION COMPONENT IN A HEALTH SERVICES DEMONSTRATION PROJECT CONDUCTED BY WHO, UNICEF, THE NATIONAL HEALTH MINISTRIES, AND OTHERS. IN CAMEROON, THE ACTIVITY IS BASED ON NURSE TRAINING IN THE OCEAC HEADQUARTERS, WITH A FIELD DEMONSTRATION PROJECT FOR IN-SERVICE TRAINING OF NURSES. EVALUATOR FOUND OPERATIONS IN CHAD TO BE OF QUESTIONABLE VALUE; OTHER ACTIVITIES JUDGED WORTHY OF CONTINUED SUPPORT IF PROGRAM OBJECTIVES CAN BE CLEARLY DEFINED AND RELATED ADMINISTRATIVE PROBLEMS RESOLVED EVALUATOR RECOMMENDED TERMINATION OF ACTIVITIES IN CHAD AS SOON AS IS PRACTICAL; REVISION OF EXISTING PROP TO PROVIDE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES; AND EXTENSION OF OTHER ACTIVITIES UNTIL 3/30/76 TO PROVIDE AN ADDITIONAL OPERATIONAL YEAR AND A YEAR FOR FINAL EVALUATION. UNIV PITT'S USE TO LARGELY UNTRAINED GRADUATE STUDENTS IN FIELD WORK HAS PUT AN EXTRA WORK LOAD ON FIELD STAFF. IN ADDITION, U OF PITT UNDERESTIMATED TECHNICAL DEMANDS OF PROJECT AND DID NOT PROVIDE REQUIRED EXPERT CONSULTANTS IN THE AREA OF SURVEY DESIGN, SAMPLING, AND STATISTICAL ANALYSIS. EVALUATOR SUGGESTED A MORITORIUM ON USE OF GRADUATE STUDENTS; REDUCTION OF ON-CAMPUS STAFF BY 50%; PROVISION OF EXPERT CONSULTANTS TO FIELD STAFF; AND PRODUCTION OF QUANTIFIABLE WORK PLANS. EVALUATION HINDERED BY THE LACK OF A CLEAR ADMINISTRATIVE FOCUS CONCERNING PROJECT OBJECTIVES, AS WELL AS BY THE ALMOST TOTAL LACK OF AVAILABLE BASELINE DATA AND THE LACK OF FEEDBACK ON TRAINING MATERIALS.
Descriptors_Topical: Health care planning|Health policy|Evaluation methodology|Health delivery|Pilot projects|Health|Nursing education|Rural areas|Medical education|Limited data plus
Title: REGIONAL PUBLIC HEALTH TRAINING (OCEAC) - - REPORT OF PUBLIC HEALTH CONSULTANT.

Abstract: THIS REPORT RELATES THE ENCOUNTERS & EVENTS WHICH DR ALBERT HENN EXPERIENCED DURING HIS PARTICIPATION IN THE JOURNEES MEDICALES INTERNATL HEALTH CONFERENCE HELD AT THE UNIV CENTER FOR HEALTH SCIENCES  (CUSS) DEC 17-23, 1973.DR HENN ATTENDED THE CONFERENCE TO ADD TO THE AMERICAN PRESENCE THERE,TO BECOME ORIENTED TO THE STATUS OF USAID HEALTH PROJS IN CENTRAL AFRICA,AND TO PREPARE FOR PROJ REVIEW OF CUSS SCHEDULED FOR FEB 1974.AID INVOLVEMENT IN CUSS,AS PLANNED,CONSISTED OF SUPPORT FOR THE CONSTRCTN OF AN OUTPATIENT CNTR AND A PEDIATRICS & MATERNITY UNIT OF THE HOSPITAL ALONG WITH PROVISION OF FACULTY SUPPORT & PARTIC TRNG.THIS REPORT STATES THAT,AS OF DEC 1973,AID'S INVOLVEMENT IN THIS MULTI-DONOR PROJ COMPRISED ONLY A CONTRACT WITH HARVARD UNIV TO PROVIDE THE MATRNL/CH HLTH COMPONENTS OF TRNG & SRVCS AT THE CENTER. AN ISSUE STRESSED AT THE CONFERENCE BY CAMEROUN'S PRESIDENT,EL HADJ AHMADON AHIDJO,IS THAT THE COUNTRY'S HLTH SRVCS & INSTITS SHOULD DEVOTE MUCH CONCERN TO A NATL EFFORT TO DOUBLE CAMEROUN'S POPULATION.THIS REPORT RECOMMENDS THAT AID CAPITALIZE ON THIS BY INTEGRATING FAM PLANNING TYPE HLTH EDUC WITH STANDARD MATRNL/CH HLTH CURRICULUMS.ANOTHER GENERAL RECOMMENDATION IS THAT ALL CONSULTANTS/ADVISORS ASSIGNED TO THIS & OTHER HLTH PROJS IN FRANCOPHONE AFRICA SHOULD HAVE A STRONG WORKING KNOWLEDGE OF FRENCH. PROJECT-SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS: 1)THE SECOND PHYSICIAN MEMBER OF THE HARVARD TEAM SHOULD BE IDENTIFIED AND SENT TO CUSS AS SOON AS POSSIBLE.THIS PHYSICIAN WOULD SHARE THE CLINICAL WORKLOAD OF THE OB/GYN DEPT IN ADDITION TO HAVING TEACHING DUTIES. 2)AID SHOULD CONSIDER THE POSSIBILITY OF SUPPORTING THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A PARAMEDICAL TRNG PROGRAM AT CUSS AND SHOULD DEVELOP THE CAPACITY TO PROVIDE ASSISTANCE IN LOCAL HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENT & TASK ANALYSIS,PROBLEM-ORIENTED CURRICULUM DEISGN,COMPETENCY-BASED TRAINING,AND IMAGE BUILDING FOR NEW PARAMEDICAL PROFESSIONALS.

Abstract: THE WEST AFRICAN RICE DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION (WARDA) IS THE AGENT OF TWELVE SOVEREIGN STATES FOR COORDINATING AND FURTHERING THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE RICE INDUSTRY IN AND AMONG THOSE COUNTRIES. THE OBJECTIVES AND PROGRAMS ELABORATED BY THE ASSOCIATION APPEAR TO BE CONSISTENT WITH ITS PURPOSES AND THE ELEMENTS OF THE PROGRAM IMPLEMENTED SO FAR HAVE MET ADEQUATE STANDARDS OF PROFESSSIONAL EXCELLENCE. WARDA IS A NEW, INNOVATIVE AND EXPANDING ORGANIZATION. IT IS UNIQUE BECAUSE OF ITS DEPENDENCY UPON A VARIETY OF DONORS, ITS FOCUS ON A SPECIFIC COMMODITY SYSTEM, THE SCALE OF ITS INTERNATIONAL RELATIONSHIPS AND INTERCULTURAL CONSTRAINTS. WARDA IS WELL-ORGANIZED AND MANAGED WITH DUE ALLOWANCES FOR FACTORS NOTED ABOVE. THE COORDINATED TRIALS PROJECT ENABLES THE MEMBER STATES TO CARRY ON A COMPLETE SCOPE OF ADAPTIVE RESEARCH IN RICE AT A VERY LOW COST. THE EVALUATORS MAKE 19 SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS ABOUT ORGANIZATION AND MANAGEMENT, THE FINANCIAL SYSTEM, THE RESEARCH PROGRAM AND THE DEVELOPMENT DEPARTMENT. RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDE: (1)PURSUE WARDA'S PRESENT COURSE OF INSTITUTIONAL DEVELOPMENT; (2)COMPLETE THE DEFINITION AND PLANNINGOF WARDA'S ROLE AND COURSES OF ACTION AS RAPIDLY AS FEASIBLE; AND (3)CONSIDER WARDA'S ROLE IN ASSISTING THE PRODUCTION AND MARKETING ACTIVITIES IN THE MEMBER STATES.

Abstract: THE CAMPAIGN FOR THE ERADICATION OF MALARIA (CEM) HAS COMPLIED WITH THE MAJOR PART OF THE TECHNICAL RECOMMENDATIONS MADE BY THE GROUP WHICH REVIEWED THE PROGRAM IN 1971. THE PROGRAM HAS BEEN ASSIGNED PRIORITY BECAUSE OF THE IMPORTANCE WHICH MALARIA HAS AMONG THE MANY PROBLEMS OF THE COUNTRY AND EXPECIALLY IN AREAS UNDERGOING DEVELOPMENT. THE SUBSTANTIAL INCREASE IN FINANCIAL AND MORAL SUPPORT, THE RECUPERATION OF ADMINISTRATIVE FLEXIBILITY, THE CLOSER ASSOCIATION OF THE SUPERINTENDENCY WITH THE HIGHEST LEVELS OF THE MINISTRY OF HEALTH, ITS CAPACITY TO OBTAIN SUPPORT OF OTHER INSTITUTIONS AND TO FURNISH LEADERSHIP TO PERSONNEL UNDER ITS DIRECTION HAVE RENEWED THE INTEREST AND ENTHUSIASM IN CAMPAIGN PERSONNEL AT ALL LEVELS. THIS IS NOW BEING REFLECTED IN EVIDENT IMPROVEMENT IN THE CARRYING OUT OF OPERATIONS IN QUANTITY AND QUALITY AND IN THE REDUCTION OF MALARIOMETRIC INDICES. THE EVALUATORS ANALYZED THE PROGRAMMING OF THE MALARIA ERADICATION GOALS UP TO 1980 AND CONSIDER THAT THE GOAL OF AN ANNUAL INCIDENCE OF 0.5 PER 1,000 INHABITANTS FOR 1980 IS POSSIBLE, TAKING INTO ACCOUNT PRESENT KNOWLEDGE OF MALARIA EPIDEMIOLOGY IN THE COUNTRY AND THE FAVORABLE RESPONSE TO ATTACK MEASURES. IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT TWO SPECIFIC STUDIES BE CONTINED AS SHOULD COMPLEMENTARY MEASURES TO DDT SPRAYING.
Descriptors_Topical: MALARIA|Disease prevention and control

Title: EVALUATION REPORT; MALARIA ERADICATION PROGRAM; BRAZIL

Abstract: THE EVALUATORS FOUND THAT THE INSTITUTO DE FOMENTO Y ASESORIA MUNICIPAL (IFAM) OF COSTA RICA HAD ACCOMPLISHED A GREAT DEAL OF WORK IN TERMS OF NUMBERS OF LOANS PROCESSED AND APPROVED, NUMBERS OF MUNICIPAL EMPLOYEES TRAINED AND ADVISED, AND CERTAIN PIONEERING EFFORTS IN RESEARCH AND SPECIAL PROJECTS. TO DATE, IFAM'S EFFORTS HAD A POSITIVE IMPACT ON THE MUNICIPALITIES. THE EVALUATORS FOUND SIX MAJOR AREAS IN WHICH IFAM HAS FALLEN SHORT OF ITS GOAL OF MUNICIPAL REFORM: (1)IT HAS NOT DEVOTED SUFFICIENT ATTENTION TO GENERAL ADMINISTRATIVE NEEDS AND PROBLEMS; (2)IT HAS NOT YET BECOME INVOLVED IN THE DEVELOPMENT PLANNING PROCESS; (3)IT HAS NOT DEVOTED SUFFICIENT ATTENTION TO MUNICIPALITIES MOST IN NEED OF COUNSEL AND ADVICE; (4)THERE HAS BEEN A DILUTION AND DISTRACTION OF EFFORT, STAFF, AND PERHAPS FUNDS AWAY FROM THE TWO KEY DEPARTMENTS OF OPERATIONS AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE; (5)PLANNING OF IFAM'S ACTIVITIES HAS NOT BEEN SUFFICIENTLY RATIONAL AND DETAILED; AND (6)FINANCIAL PLANNING HAS BEEN DELAYED TOO LONG. MAJOR RECOMMENDATIONS REVOLVE AROUND: (1)STRENGTHENING AND IMPROVING THE COORDINATION OF THE KEY DEPARTMENTS; (2)BETTER IN TEGRATION OF IFAM'S RESEARCH ACTIVITIES WITH KEY DEPARTMENTS; AND (3)IMPROVING ADMINISTATION, PROGRAM PLANNING AND FINANCIAL PLANNING CAPABILITIES.
Descriptors_Topical: Municipal level|Public administration|Rural development|Institution building|Management training
Title: IFAM AFTER TWO YEARS; FINAL REPORT

Abstract: DESPITE SIX OR MORE YEARS SINCE THE ECUADORIAN GOVERNMENT FORMALLY INSTITUTED OFFICIAL FAMILY PLANNING EFFORTS AT THE NATIONAL LEVEL, THE TOTAL IMPACT ON FAMILY PLANNING PRACTICE IS ALMOST INCONSEQUENTIAL. THE GOVERNMENT'S OWN REPORTS CLAIM LESS THAN 2 PER CENT OF ELIGIBLE WOMEN AS HAVING ACCEPTED CONTRACEPTION. A COMBINATION OF ADMINISTRATIVE WEAKNESS AND APATHY, IF NOT OPPOSITION, IN KEY POSITIONS IN THE OFFICIAL PROGRAM MILITATED AGAINST GREATER ACHIEVEMENTS, AT LEAST UNTIL THE CHANGE IN LEADERSHIP AS RECENTLY AS MAY 1972. RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDE: (1) AID SHOULD GIVE EMPHASIS TO STRENGTHENING INFRASTRUCTURE, WHILE CONTINUING TO SUPPORT DEVELOPMENT OF FAMILY PLANNING SERVICES WHENEVER THEY APPEAR OR SEEM POSSIBLE; (2) EVERY EFFORT SHOULD BE MADE TO INSTITUTE COORDINATION OF PUBLIC SECTOR EFFORTS IN FAMILY PLANNING SERVICE DELIVERY AND INFORMATION/EDUCATION ACTIVITIES; (3) IN THE NEAR FUTURE, ALL FINANCING OF PRIVATE SECTOR PROGRAMS IN ECUADOR SHOULD BE TURNED OVER TO OTHER (NON-AID/ECUADOR) FUNDING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AGENCIES WORKING IN THE FAMILY PLANNING FIELD; (4) EMPHASIS SHOULD BE PLACED ON A PHASED CONCENTRATED APPROACH OF SERVICES; AND (5) EXPERIMENTAL PILOT PROJECTS SHOULD BE CREATED.
Descriptors_Topical: Family planning|Government policy
Personal_Author: WISHIK, SAMUEL M.|MEDINA, ANTONIO S.|BLOMBERG, ROBERT C.
Title: ASSESSMENT OF THE POPULATION ACTIVITIES UNDERWAY IN ECUADOR FUNDED BY AID/ECUADOR

Abstract: THE LOAN HAS FINANCED THE CONSTRUCTION OF 55 HEALTH CENTERS PLUS MEDICINES, EQUIPMENT AND VEHICLES FOR USE IN MSP'S (MINISTRY OF PUBLIC HEALTH) HEALTH CENTERS AND PUMAR (RURAL MOBILE HEALTH) PROGRAM. BASICALLY, AID HAS DONE WHAT IT PROMISED TO DO IN THE LOAN, YET THE LOAN HAS NOT PRODUCED AN EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE HEALTH SYSTEM FOR POOR PEOPLE TODAY. THE GOVERNMENT OF NICARAGUA (GON) HAS NOT PROVIDED THE GOOD ADMINISTRATION AND RESOURCES REQUIRED FOR SUCCESS. RESULTS ARE DISAPPOINTING IF THE SERVICES TO BE ANTICIPATED BY NICARAGUANS IN THE FUTURE ARE ESTIMATED BASED ON THE SERVICES ACTUALLY BEING RECEIVED. NEVERTHELESS, THE LOAN HAS HELPED CREATE AN INFRASTRUCTURE FOR HEALTH SERVICES THAT COULD BE MORE FRUITFULLY USED IN THE FUTURE THAN IT IS BEING USED IN THE PRESENT. DESPITE LOW PATIENT LOADS, THERE HAVE BEEN SOME PRACTICAL BENEFITS TO POOR PEOPLE FROM THE LOAN. USAID MANAGEMENT OF THE LOAN HAS BEEN EFFECTIVE WHEN FOCUSED ON THE CONSTRUCTION AND PROCUREMENT ASPECTS OF THE PROJECT BUT INEFFECTIVE IN GETTING THE GON TO PROVIDE MONEY AND MANAGEMENT TALENT SUFFICIENT TO ADMINISTER THE PROJECT SUCCESSFULLY. THE EVALUATORS RECOMMEND PRACTICAL MEASURES TO IMPROVE THE PROJECT, THE EFFICIENCY OF THE SUPPORT SYSTEMS, THE PERFORMANCE OF THE HEALTH CENTERS AND MANAGEMENT IN MSP (19 RECOMMENDATIONS IN ALL).
Descriptors_Topical: Mobile health services|Rural areas|Health care|Public health care|Medical equipment|Health delivery|Health facilities
Title: EVALUATION OF A LOAN TO NICARAGUA FOR HEALTH CENTERS AND RURAL MOBILE HEALTH UNITS (AID LOAN 524-L-023)

Abstract: THE EVALUATOR'S OVERALL IMPRESSION OF THE PARAGUAYAN EDUCATIONAL EFFORT AND THE AID PROJECT IS A FAVORABLE ONE. CONSIDERING THE CONSTRAINTS OF THE NATION'S ECONOMY, THE POLITICAL PROBLEMS INHERENT IN EDUCATION, AND THE STAGE OF TECHNICAL SKILL AMONG ITS EDUCATORS, THE PUBLIC SCHOOL SYSTEM IS MAKING CONSIDERABLE STRIDES IN "TOOLING UP" FOR EDUCATIONAL IMPROVEMENTS. IN THE FIELD, TEACHERS ARE READY TO DEVOTE CONSIDERABLE EFFORT TO ACHIEVE A SIGNIFICANT IMPROVEMENT. GIVEN A CONTINUITY IN THE FLOW OF LEADERSHIP, TRAINING, AND SUPPORT FOR THEIR EFFORTS, THE OUTLOOK FOR THEIR SUCCESS IS GOOD. THE NEW CURRICULUM IS AN EXCELLENT PIECE OF WORK. THE EVALUATORS MADE THREE GENERAL PROGRAM RECOMMENDATIONS: (1)A COMPREHENSIVE ASSESSMENT OF PARAGUAY'S CURRENT AND FUTURE MANPOWER NEEDS SHOULD BE UNDERTAKEN; (2)AN INTENSIVE TRAINING PROGRAM IN PLANNING FOR ALL LEVELS OF PERSONNEL SHOULD BE DESIGNED AND IMPLEMENTED; AND (3)A COMPREHENSIVE SELF-EVALUATION AND MONITORING SYSTEM SHOULD BE DESIGNED IN CONJUNCTION WITH KEY MINISTRY OF EDUCATION (MOE) PERSONNEL. THEY ALSO MADE MANY PROJECT-SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS ON SUCH MATTERS AS CURRICULUM, TRAINING OF EDUCATIONAL SPECIALISTS, TEXTBOOK PRODUCTION, AND THE ORGANIZATION AND ADMINISTRATION OF THE (1)ADMINISTRATION AND FINANCE, (2)REGIONAL EDUCATIONAL CENTERS, AND (3)COUNSELLING AND GUIDANCE DEPARTMENTS OF THE MOE.
Descriptors_Topical: Primary education|Curriculum design|Teacher training|Educational development|Textbooks|Educational planning|Educational policy|National level|Educational materials|Secondary education

Title: FINAL REPORT ON THE EVALUATION OF THE ELEMENTARY & SECONDARY EDUCATION GRANT & LOAN PROJECT IN PARAGUAY

Abstract: ALTHOUGH THE CENTER FOR POPULATION AND DEVELOPMENT STUDIES (CEPD) HAS ATTAINED SOME RECOGNITION AS A POPULATION RESEARCH AND PROMOTION INSTITUTION, IT HAS FAILED TO BUILD A PERMANENT HIGHLY PROFESSIONAL DEMOGRAPHIC STAFF BECAUSE OF THE LACK OF A NATIONAL POSITIVE POPULATION POLICY, OVERT LIMITATIONSON ITS ACTIVITIES, AND CHANGES IN EMPHASIS DURING ITS EIGHT -YEAR EXISTENCE. DIRECTION HAS BEEN UNSTABLE AND INDIVIDUAL STAFF MEMBERS HAVE NOT WORKED TOGETHER TOWARD A WELL-DEFINED GOAL. CEPD OFFICIALS INDICATE THAT SEVERAL CEPD PERSONNEL AND MANY OF ITS ONGOING FUNCTIONS WILL BE TERMINATED IN JULY IF AID OR OTHER EXTERNAL FINANCING IS NOT FORTHCOMING. SOME OF THESE ACTIVITIES AND PERSONNEL ARE INCONSISTENT WITH THE RECOMMENDATIONS OF THIS EVALUATION AND FAILURE TO MEET THE CEPD PAYROLL FOR AN INTERIM PERIOD MAY BE THE MOST EFFECTIVE WAY OF ASSURING LONGER-TERM FUNDING FOR THE KEY CROPS. THE EVALUATOR(S) MADE 8 RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDING; (1)AND FUNDING FOR THE NEXT TWO YEARS SHOULD BE POSITED ON THE ASSUMPTION AND, IF POSSIBLE, AN UNDERSTANDING WITH THE GOVERNMENT OF PERU (GOP), THAT CEPD WILL BE IMMEDIATELY REORGANIZED, RESTAFFED, AND ABSORBED AS A UNIT AS EARLY AS FEASIBLE INTO AN EXISTING GOP AGENCY; AND (2)THE MAJOR EMPHASIS DURING THE COMING TWO YEARS SHOULD BE ON THE TRAINING AND FORMATION OF A KEY PERUVIAN CORPS STAFF OF POPULATION AND DEMOGRAPHIC EXPERTS.
Descriptors_Topical: DEMOGRAPHY|FAMILY PLANNING|Population policy|Population planning
Title: Human resources and population studies

Abstract: THIS PROJECT BEGAN IN 1970. ITS ESSENTIAL FEATURE WAS EARLY INSTALLATION OF WATER AND DIP FACILITIES TO OBTAIN SOME IMMEDIATE SHORT-TERM ACCEPTANCE OF CHANGE DUE TO SHORT-TERM IMPROVEMENT IN MASAI ENVIRONMENT. GENERALLY, MASAI'S WILLINGNESS TO JOIN THE PROGRAM IS EXCEEDING THE CURRENT STAFF AND MATERIAL RESOURCES FOR IMPLEMENTATION. THE GOT HAS PROVIDED STRONG LEADERSHIP AND SUPPORT. THE SECTOR GOAL HAS BEEN REVISED TO: OBTAIN THE HIGHEST NATIONAL BEEF PRODUCTION POSSIBLE WITH ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION AND IMPROVEMENT. THE PURPOSE HAS BEEN REVISED TO: REACH A SUSTAINED HIGH LEVEL OF OFFTAKE IN THE MASAI DISTRICT CONSISTENT WITH PROPER LAND USE, RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, AND TANZANIAN SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC GOALS. THE EOPS AND THE PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION PLAN WERE ALSO REVISED. IT WAS RECOMMENDED THAT STAFFING AND TRAINING BE EXPANDED. RECOMMENDATIONS IN THE AREAS OF RANGE MANAGEMENT, MARKETING, AND ANIMAL PRODUCTION AND DISEASE INCLUDE: SUBDIVIDE RANCHING ASSOCIATIONS INTO MANAGEABLE UNITS AND DEVELOP PLANS FOR EACH UNIT; COLLECT AND RECORD DATA ON HERD COMPOSITION; DEVELOP A STANDARD OF SELECTION, DESIGN UPGRADING AND IMPROVED ANIMAL HUSBANDRY MANAGEMENT PLANS; ORGANIZE MARKETS WITH SUPPORTING SERVICES AND PHYSICAL FACILITIES; AND FACILITATE CREDIT ARRANGEMENTS TO MEET DEVELOPMENT AND PRODUCTION REQUIREMENTS.
Descriptors_Topical: Land development|Natural resource management|Animal husbandry|Range management|Water resources|Natural resource development|On the job training|Participants|Disease prevention and control|Animal diseases|Livestock|Agricultural product marketing|Associations
Personal_Author: LICHT, IRVING H.|GALLI, MICHAEL|MCELROY, GEORGE B.
Title: MASAI LIVESTOCK AND RANGE MANAGEMENT PROJECT; EVALUATION REPORT

Abstract: THE CURRENT BASIS FOR THE MAJOR CEREALS PROJECT OF WEST AFRICA IS PROVIDED BY THE GRANT AGREEMENT BETWEEN USAID AND THE SCIENTIFIC, TECHNICAL AND RESEARCH COMMISSION (STRC) OF THE ORGANIZATION FOR AFRICAN UNITY (OAU). THE PURPOSE OF THE GRANT IS TO ASSIST STRC IN THE ESTABLISHMENT AND DEVELOPMENT OF A COORDINATED RESEARCH, TESTING, AND MULTIPLICATION PROGRAM FOR STAPLE FOOD GRAINS AND TRAINING OF A CADRE OF AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH SCIENTISTS IN CENTRAL AND WEST AFRICAN STATES. THE DEVELOPMENT OF IMPROVED VARIETIES OF MAJOR CEREALS HAS PROGRESSED REASONABLY WELL, WITH NOTABLE NEW BREEDING AND DEVELOPMENT IN MAIZE; SIGNIFICANT BUT SLOW PROGRESS IN SORGHUM; AND COMPARATIVELY LESS PROGRESS IN MILLET. SIGNIFICANT PROGRESS WAS NOTED IN STIMULATING AND IMPROVING COMMUNICATION BETWEEN CEREAL RESEARCH PERSONNEL IN WEST AFRICA. DUE TO DELAYS IN PARTICIPANT TRAINING, THERE WILL BE ONLY A LIMITED NUMBER OF NIGERIANS TRAINED WHEN THE PROJECT IS TERMINATED AND THEY WILL BE LACKING IN EXPERIENCE. STRENGTHENING THE STRC COORDINATION UNIT IS OF GREAT IMPORTANCE TO THE SUCCESS OF THE PROJECT. THE EVALUATORS MAKE 12 PROJECT-SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS.
Descriptors_Topical: SORGHUM|Millet|Maize|Cereals|Agricultural research|Participants|Varietal research
Inst_Author: 002680 - USAID. Bur. for Africa. Ofc. of Central and West Africa Regional
Title: EVALUATION REPORT; STRC/OAU JOINT PROJECT J.P.-26; MAJOR CEREALS IMPROVEMENT PROJECT; WEST AFRICA; AID 625-11-130-305

Abstract: THE TEAM CONCLUDED THAT THE ORIGINAL PROJECT OBJECTIVES WERE TOO BROAD IN SCOPE AND PURPOSE, PARTICULARLY GIVEN THE RESOURCES AVAILABLE TO AID, THE CONTRACTOR, THE ORGANIZATION FOR THE CONTROL OF ENDEMIC DISEASES IN CENTRAL AFRICA (OCEAC) AND THE PARTICIPATING COUNTRIES. THE PROJECT DOCUMENTATION HAD BEEN CHANGED ON NUMEROUS OCCASIONS WITH THE RESULT THAT PRECISE PROJECT OBJECTIVES COULD NOT BE DETERMINED. AMONG USEFUL EFFORTS UNDERWAY WERE: (1)TRAINING NURSES AND OTHER HEALTH WORKERS; (2)DEVELOPING BACKGROUND INFORMATION ON HEALTH BELIEFS AND PRACTICES; AND (3)DEVELOPING A COMMUNITY ORGANIZATION BASED ON TRADITIONAL VILLAGE AND COMMUNITY LEADERSHIP. LITTLE EFFECTIVE WORK HAD BEEN DONE TO ESTABLISH THE BASE LINES AND SCIENTIFIC INQUIRY METHODS REQUIRED IN THE CONTRACT. LITTLE WAS BEING PRODUCED THAT WOULD BE USEFUL TO OCEAC IN STRENGTHENING ITS ORGANIZATIONAL CAPABILITY. THE EVALUATORS AGREED WITH OCEAC'S CONCEPT OF LIMITING THE SCOPE OF THE PROJECT TO THE INTRODUCTION OF HEALTH EDUCATION ASPECTS INTO THE VARIOUS COMPONENTS OF BASIC HEALTH SERVICES. RECOMMENDATIONS INCLUDE: (1)LIMIT FIELD STAFF TO FOUR; (2)EXTEND THE PROJECT UNTIL JUNE 30, 1976; (3)DEVELOP A NEW PROP ACCEPTABLE TO ALL PARTIES; AND (4)ESTABLISH GUIDELINES FOR THE DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM ACTIVITIES AND THE CONTRACTOR WORK PLAN.
Descriptors_Topical: Primary health care|Public health care|Medical education|Educational materials|Manuals and handbooks|Health education
Title: EVALUATION REPORT; OCEAC REGIONAL PUBLIC HEALTH TRAINING PROJECT; PROJECT NO. 625-11-540-510

Abstract: USAID/ETHIOPIA FORMULATED THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR LOAN (ASL) IN AN ATTEMPT TO (1)IMPROVE THE ORGANIZATION AND ADMINISTRATION OF AGRICULTURAL PLANNING INSTITUTIONS AND FISCAL PERFORMANCE AND (2)TO INCREASE ETHIOPIA'S ABSORPTIVE CAPACITY. THE LOAN MADE AVAILABLE A SURFEIT OF RESOURCES CAUSING AN INCREASE IN PROJECT IDENTIFICATION AND PLANNING. THE LOAN COVERED ONLY LOCAL CURRENCY EXPENSES. AFTER THE MONEY HAD BEEN SPENT, PROJECTS WERE ATTRIBUTED TO ASL AND ENDORSED BY USAID. THE EVALUATORS RANKED ASL-ATTRIBUTED ACTIVITIES BY THEIR EFFECT ON INCOME DISTRIBUTION AND EMPLOYMENT AND CONCLUDED THAT THE IMPACT OF THE ACTIVITIES VARIED CONSIDERABLY. CONCLUSIONS INCLUDE; (1)THE BASIC FINANCIAL UNDERTAKINGS WERE ADEQUATELY FULFILLED; AND (2)CAPACITY TO PLAN AND IMPLEMENT DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES PROBABLY INCREASED. RECOMMENDATIONS FOR ANY FUTURE LOANS INCLUDE: (1)INCLUDE AN EQUITY CRITERION; AND (2)CONSIDER REQUIRING THAT SELF-FINANCE OF AGRICULTURAL CAPITAL EXPENDITURE SHOULD GROW AS FAST OR FASTER THAN (A)DOMESTIC REVENUES OR (B)THE SELF-FINANCE COMPONENT OF THE CAPITAL BUDGET, WHICHEVER IS LARGER. THE EVALUATORS ALSO RECOMMENDED THAT THE LOAN SHOULD MOVE FROM PRIMARILY SUPPLYING A TEMPORARY GLUT OF RESOURCES IN AGRICULTURE TO BECOMING MORE SPECIALIZED IN DIRECTION AND PURPOSE.
Descriptors_Topical: Development project design|Development project implementation|Development project evaluation|Agricultural policy|Agricultural planning|Institution building|Agricultural finance|Debt servicing|Income distribution|Sector loans
Title: EVALUATION OF THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR LOANS FUNDED BY USAID/ETHIOPIA

Abstract: THE UNDERGRADUATE PROGRAM IN PHASE I OF THE COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY (CSU)/AID VETERINARY EDUCATION PROJECT HAS BEEN SUCCESSFULLY CARRIED OUT,ALTHOUGH THERE ARE SOME AREAS WHERE IMPROVEMENTS MAY BE NECESSARY. THE AVAILABILITY OF STUDENTS FOR ADVANCED TRAINING BASICALLY ALLOWED THE PROGRAM TO GO INTO THE SECOND PHASE OF EXPANDED RESEARCH AND POST GRADUATE TRAINING. THE OVERALL PERFORMANCE IN CARRYING OUT THE OBJECTIVES OF PHASE II FOR THE FIRST YEAR AND A HALF HAS NOT BEEN EFFECTIVE. HOWEVER, WITH THE INITIATION OF CERTAIN REFORMS AND IMPROVEMENTS THERE IS NO REASON WHY THE PROGRAM CANNOT BE COMPLETED EFFECTIVELY. THE CURRENT CSU TEAM HAS DONE LITTLE TO PROMOTE OR DEVELOP GRADUATE TRAINING. THERE APPEARS TO BE NO PLAN DEVELOPED AND INDEED THERE EVEN SEEMS TO BE ACTIVE OPPOSITION TO A GRADUATE PROGRAM. RESEARCH IS A KEY FACOTR IN DEVELOPING A GRADUATE PROGRAM BUT THE CURRENT CSU TEAM HAS INITIATED ONLY A VERY LIMITED RESEARCH EFFORT. GREATER EFFORT MUST BE MADE TO RECRUIT TEAM MEMBERS WHO CAN ACHIEVE THE OBJECTIVES OF THE CONTRACT AND WHO CAN PERFORM BOTH PHYSICALLY AND EMOTIONALLY IN A DEVELOPING NATION. GSU MUST MAKE EVERY EFFORT TO DEVELOP RESEARCH AND FIND WAYS FOR AFRICANIZING THE CLINICAL STUDIES AREA.
Descriptors_Topical: Higher education|Veterinary medicine
Title: COLORADO STATE U./AID VETERINARY EDUCATION PROJECT AT U. OF NAIROBI; A CRITIQUE (DISTRIBUTION IN AID AND CSU ONLY)

Abstract: DESCRIBES METHODOLOGY OF OPPORTUNITIES INDUSTRIALIZATION CENTER (OIC). SUMMARIZES PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION. DISCUSSES PROGRAMS AND STAFFING PATTERNS IN GHANA AND NIGERIA. LOCAL SUPPORT AND INVOLVEMENT OF BUSINESS, INDUSTRY, GOVERNMENT ARE EXAMINED IN THE 2 COUNTRIES. COSTS AND BENEFITS OF OIC PROGRAMS ARE COMPUTED.
Descriptors_Topical: Educational methods|Vocational training|Nonformal education|Educational research|Cost benefit analysis
Title: SECOND EVALUATION OF OIC INTERNATIONAL AND ITS PROGRAMS IN GHANA AND NIGERIA

Abstract: Evaluates 3 African higher education programs sponsored by USAID - designed to assist African nations in meeting their needs for trained high and middle-level manpower.  These are:  African Scholarship Program of American Universities (ASPAU), African Graduate Scholarship Program (AFGRAD), and Inter-African University Scholarship Program (INTERAF). Evaluation is based on sample of program entrants thru 1971. In general, the programs contributed to achieving their purpose. There is, however, a demand for post-secondary, technical, non-degree training that is not well-addressed by existing African or donor programs. Only 35.7% of the ASPAU participants repatriated.  The undergraduates were young, impressionable, and many became "Americanized". The repatriated ASPAU graduate frequently has not been well-integrated back into African society. For AFGRAD, repatriation (83.3%) and continued residence in Africa has not been a problem.  For both ASPAU and AFGRAD, scholars remain outside Africa due to greater availability of jobs and higher salaries. Marriage to foreign nationals does not appear to be a primary factor associated with the decision to live outside Africa. Because INTERAF scholars do not leave Africa and university tuition is lower, the INTERAF program is the most cost-effective of the three. AID's basic costs of getting scholars into high priority development jobs are:  ASPAU $52,420; AFGRAD $29,518; INTERAF $14,432. Returned participants lack practical training.  Scholars need applied work in lieu of or along with theoretical training.  AFGRAD should be limited to short-term (1-2 year) skills acquisition including work study experience.  AFGRAD Scholars should be required to return to their home countries and future candidates should not be accepted from countries to which scholars are not returned. In general, USAID should concentrate on non-degree programs and ensure that educational priorities are relevant to development needs as perceived by African governments rather than African and US universities. Includes bibliography citing regional and country-specific papers dealing with higher education, manpower needs, and unemployment.
Descriptors_Topical: Graduate education|Undergraduate education|Participants|Educational delivery|Evaluation methodology|Evaluation|Education for development
Title: EVALUATION OF ASPAU, AFGRAD, AND INTERAF : IMPACT OF REGIONAL SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAMS ON MANPOWER NEEDS IN AFRICA.

Abstract: EVALUATES PROJ PERFORMANCE FROM 4/1/63-6/1/73 IN THE PHILIPPINES; USAID PROVIDED TECH ASSIST TO THE PHILIPPINES BUREAU OF PUBLIC WORKS & THE NATL IRRIGATION ASSOC (NIA) TO IMPROVE PLNNG & DEVLPMNT OF WATER RESOURCES ON A NATIONWIDE BASIS. PROJ MANAGER DETAILS PROJ HISTORY & ACCOMPLISHMENTS IN PERFORMING THE EVAL, EMPHASIZING THE NIA'S MAGAT RIVER PROJ FEASIBILITY STUDY (7/71-6/73). US BUREAU OF RECLAMATION(BUREC) TECH ASSIST TEAM INCLUDED A PROJ ENGINEER,HYDROLOGIST,SOILS SCIENTIST,GROUNDWATER ENGINEER & A FIELD ENGINEER. THE MAGAT RIVER STUDY CONSISTED OF 3 MAIN SUBJ AREAS -- HYDROLOGY,ECON & LAND RESOURCES & ENGRG. OTHER ACTIVITIES INCLUDED SOIL SAMPLE TESTS & A SOCIAL & ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STUDY BY THE INSTITUTE OF PLNNG,UNIV OF THE PHILIPPINES. ON 10/10/71 AN UNUSUAL FLOOD OCCURRED ON THE MAGAT RIVER CAUSING OVER 14 MIL PESO DAMAGE. ADDITIONAL STUDY OF THE SEDIMENT DISCHARGE OF THE MAGAT RIVER INDICATED THAT THE FUTURE RESERVOIR BEHIND THE SELECTED DAMSITE WOULD BE COMPLETELY FILLED WITH SEDIMENT WITHIN 100 YRS & ITS ECON USEFULNESS SERIOUSLY IMPAIRED WELL BEFORE THAT TIME. REPORT CONCLUDES THAT THE GOP CAPABILITY TO PLAN FOR A SINGLE PROJ WAS FAIRLY WELL-DEVLPED. HOWEVER,CONTINUED ASSIST WILL BE REQUIRED TO EXPAND SUCH PLNNG TO A BASIN OR A NATL BASIS. EVALUATOR RECOMMENDS THAT ADEQUATE FUNDS BE PROGRAMMED TO COLLECT BASIC DATA SUCH AS STREAMFLOWS & SEDIMENTATION LOADS. RESPONSIBILITY FOR WATER RESOURCES PLNNG SHOULD BE CENTRALIZED--EITHER WITHIN A NEW AGENCY OR A COMMITTEE CONSISTING OF MEMBERS OF EXISTING AGENCIES. FUTURE TECH ASSIST SHOULD BE DIRECTED TOWARD COUNTRY-WIDE PLNNG. IN-COUNTRY & PARTIC TRNG SHOULD BE CONTINUED IN FIELDS SUCH AS SOILS & WATER LAB TECHNIQUES & PROCEDURES,HYDROLOGY,GROUNDWATER ENGRG AND/OR GEOLOGY,DRAINAGE ENGRG,AGR ECON & DESIGN OF LARGE DAMS. INCENTIVES NEED TO BE DEVLPED TO PREVENT LOSS OF TALENT TO PRIVATE INDUS OR OUT-COUNTRY MIGRATIONS. ALTHOUGH THE MAGAT PROJ WAS DETERMINED TO BE FEASIBLE,CAREFUL CONSIDERATION SHOULD BE GIVEN BEFORE IMPLEMENTATION DUE TO ITS HIGH COST. THIS PROJ CONSISTS OF AN EARLIER WATER SURVEY PROJ(4920159) WHICH WAS COMBINED WITH AGR & IRRIGATION ACTIVITIES.

Title: EVALUATION OF THE WATER RESOURCES DEVELOPMENT PROJECT INCLUDING THE MAGAT RIVER PROJECT FEASIBILITY STUDY

Abstract: EVALUATES THE EDUC & FAMILY PLNNG SERVICES PROVIDED BY 2 PERUVIAN ORGANIZATIONS -- THE CHRISTIAN FAMILY MOVEMENT(MFC) & THE ASSOC OF LAYWORK FOR THE FAMILY(ATLF) -- WHICH RECEIVED ASSIST FROM USAID & FPIA(FAMILY PLNNG INTNATL ASSIST). FPIA IS ADMINISTERING & SUPERVISING THE PROJ. 2 CONSULTANTS FROM THE AMER PUBLIC HLTH ASSOC PERFORMED THE EVAL. THE CONSULTANTS WORKED IN LIMA FROM 9/11-9/21/73 & VISITED 12 OF THE 43 CLINICS. ALTHOUGH BOTH ORGANIZATIONS MADE EVERY EFFORT TO ASSEMBLE THE REQUESTED INFO, MUCH OF THE DATA WAS NOT READILY AVAILABLE. EQUIPMNT & SUPPLIES SCHEDULED IN FY73 WERE NOT RECEIVED. (A SEVERE SHORTAGE OF SPECULA CONTRIBUTED TO UNSANITARY CLINICAL PRACTICES.) A VISITING FPIA PROJ OFFICER STATED THAT WHILE ORDERS HAD BEEN PLACED WITH GSA,AS FAR AS HE COULD DETERMINE THE COMMODITIES WERE NOT PURCHASED MUCH LESS SHIPPED TO PERU. UNFORTUNATELY,THE LEADERSHIP OF ATLF (WHICH BROKE AWAY FROM MFC) WAS LED TO BELIEVE THAT THEIR PROG IS SUPERIOR TO MFC. MORE UNFORTUNATE IS THE FACT THAT MFC ALSO BELIEVES IT. AUTHORS CONCLUDE THAT WHILE THE MFC IS HANDICAPPED BY ITS SMALLER STAFF & BUDGET,BOTH PROGS HAVE ROOM FOR IMPROVEMENT. RECENTLY APPROVED BUDGETS COVER 10/01/73-9/1/74. AUTHORS RECOMMEND AT LEAST 5 YRS OF ASSIST. CONT'D FINANCING SHOULD NOT BE BASED ON THE NUMBER OF CONTRACEPTORS MCF/ATLF ARE ABLE TO ATTRACT. MFC & ATLF SHOULD BE ENCOURAGED TO PROMOTE GOVT FINANCING OF FP SERVICES NATION-WIDE. AUTHORS ALSO RECOMMEND ASSIST TO MFC/ATLF EDUC COMPONENTS SUPPORTING FORMAL TRNG OF OUTREACH WORKERS & PROVISION OF A/V EQUIP,PUBLICATIONS & MATERIALS. BOTH MFC & ATLF NEED TECH ASSIST IN DEFINING STATISTICAL REQUIREMENTS FOR USE IN SETTING REALISTIC TARGETS,ASSESSING CLINICAL LOAD & PERFORMANCE,DETERMINING STAFFING REQUIREMENTS & MAKING MODIFICATIONS TO PATIENT REGIMENS. DONORS SHOULD SEE THAT MFC & ATLF HAVE THE AMT & TYPES OF ORAL CONTRACEPTIVES REQUESTED. (BREAK-THROUGH & OTHER PROBLEMS OCCURRED BECAUSE OF A CHANGE IN THE TYPE OF ORALS SUPPLIED.) REPORT NOTES THAT MANY IMPROVMNTS COULD BE MADE TO THE CLINIC FACILITIES WITH RELATIVELY SMALL INVESTMNTS BY MFC & ATLF. FINALLY,COMMUNICATION BETWEEN MFC & ATLF MUST BE INCREASED

Title: ASSESSMENT OF THE RESPONSIBLE PARENTHOOD PROGRAMS OF THE PERUVIAN CHRISTIAN FAMILY MOVEMENT AND ASSOCIATION OF LAYWORK FOR THE FAMILY (9/10/73-9/23/73)

Abstract: EVALUATES SEMINAR OF FINANCIAL ANALYSIS AND ECONOMIC ANALYSIS CONDUCTED IN BANGUI, CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC FROM 1/12 TO 1/24/73. SEMINAR WAS FOLLOW-ON TO AN INTRODUCTORY SEMINAR ON TECHNIQUES OF PROJECT MANAGEMENT CONDUCTED AT YAOUNDE, CAMEROON, 1/24 TO 9/2/72. LIKE YAOUNDE, BANGUI WAS A FEASIBILITY TEST OF CONCEPTS WHICH MIGHT BE INCORPORATED INTO A LONG-TERM PROJECT FOR TRAINING OF GOVT OFFICIALS FROM 15 FRANCOPHONE COUNTRIES IN PROBLEMS OF PROJECT MANAGEMENT. THE EVALUATION UTILIZED INITIAL AND FINAL QUESTIONNAIRES COMPLETED BY THE PARTICIPANTS AS WELL AS PERSONAL INTERVIEWS WHERE POSSIBLE. RESULTS FROM THE PRE-SEMINAR QUESTIONNAIRE CONFIRM THAT THE YAOUNDE SEMINAR WAS SUCCESSFUL. THE PRE-SEMINAR QUESTIONNAIRE ALSO INDICATED MUCH BETTER PREPARATION OF THOSE WHO ATTENDED THE YAOUNDE SEMINAR OVER THOSE WHO HAD NOT. RESULTS OF THE POST SEMINAR QUESTIONNAIRE INDICATE THAT THE BANGUI SEMINAR WAS ALSO A SUCCESS. NO OFFICIAL DOCUMENTS REGARDING BUDGETS, COSTS OR DISBURSEMENTS WERE AVAILABLE DURING THE EVALUATION. HOWEVER, TOTAL COST WAS ESTIMATED TO BE $21,094. WITH AN AVERAGE ATTENDANCE OF 15, THE UNIT COST OF THE SEMINAR WAS $1400 PER PERSON FOR A TWO WEEK TRAINING SESSION. SEVERAL ISSUES WERE RAISED ABOUT WHICH DECISIONS MUST BE MADE TO DETERMINE OPTIMAL DESIGN FOR THE PROPOSED PROJECT, "TRAINING FOR PROJECT DESIGN AND MANAGEMENT." THESE ISSUES INCLUDE: 1) ATTENDANCE PROBLEMS CAUSED BY LATE ARRIVALS; 2) LOGISTICS PROBLEMS; 3) INSTITUTION BUILDING VS "FLOATING;" 4) LONG VS SHORT-TERM TRAINING; 5) ROTATING VS ONE-PLACE TRAINING; 6) THEORETICAL VS PRACTICAL TRAINING; 7) TRAINING OF PARTICIPANTS VS TRAINING OF TRAINERS. IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT ALTHOUGH SEVERAL OF THESE ISSUES NEED RESOLUTION, THE PROJECT SHOULD BE APPROVED AND MADE OPERATIONAL WITH A BUDGET OF ITS OWN. EVALUATIONS OF BOTH SEMINARS HAVE IDENTIFIED THE LACK OF TRAINED AFRICAN PROJECT MANAGERS AS AN OBSTACLE TO DEVELOPMENT. BOTH SEMINARS TO TEST THE FEASIBILITY OF THE INNOVATIVE CONCEPT HAVE BEEN TRIED AND HAVE BEEN SUCCESSFUL. FOLLOW-UP EVALUATIONS SHOULD CONTINUE TO BE MADE. HOWEVER, MORE ATTENTION SHOULD BE FOCUSED ON TRAINING AFRICANS TO DO OWN EVALS.
Descriptors_Topical: Evaluation methodology|Institution building|Workshops|Development project management|Education for development|Economic analysis|Management training|Financial management|Beneficiary interviews|Sampling method
Inst_Author: 000175 - USAID. Bur. for Program and Management Services. Ofc. of International Training
Title: EVALUATION OF THE BANGUI SEMINAR

Abstract: EVALUATES THE ASIAN INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY (AIT)'S NEED FOR AN IMPROVED COMPUTER SYSTEM. AIT,LOCATED IN THAILAND BUT GOVERNED BY AN INTERNATIONAL BOARD OF TRUSTEES,IS CONSIDERED THE BEST GRADUATE SCHOOL IN SE ASIA OFFERING A MASTER'S IN BOTH SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING,AND A PHD IN ENGINEERING. EVALUATION METHODOLOGY NOT DEFINED. EVALUATOR FEELS AIT HAS DEMONSTRATED LEADERSHIP IN THE FIELD OF ENGINEERING AND IS UNIQUELY SUITED TO ASSIST STUDENTS WITH THE CHALLENGES ASIA MUST SOLVE AS ITS NATIONS MOVE FROM UNDERDEVELOPED TO DEVELOPED COUNTRIES. AIT'S CONTINUED LEADERSHIP HOWEVER IS CLOSELY TIED TO THE FURTHUR DEVELOPMENT OF: 1.THE NEW CAMPUS SITE, 2.THE FACULTY, 3. THE STUDENT BODY,AND 4.ACADEMIC PROGRAMS. EVALUATOR ALSO FEELS AN IMPROVED COMPUTER SYSTEM WILL GREATLY BENEFIT AIT'S PERFORMANCE SINCE COMPUTERS HAVE PROVEN SUCCESSFUL IN ENGINEERING. ALTHOUGH MANY ASIAN COUNTRIES HAVE DEVELOPED INFORMATION AND DOCUMENTATION CENTERS,THESE MAY OFTEN DUPLICATE EFFORTS AND FALL FAR SHORT OF DESIRED GOALS. ADVANCES IN TELECOMMUNICATION,COMPUTER TECHNOLOGY,AND REPRODUCTION TECHNIQUES FAVOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF A SINGLE CENTER IN ASIA. SINCE AIT HAS ESTABLISHED A CLOSE RELATIONSHIP WITH OTHER ASIAN INSTITUTIONS AND ORGANIZATIONS AND IS IMPROVING ITS COMPUTER INFORMATION SYSTEM AND LIBRARY,EVALUATOR FEELS AIT IS THE BEST LOCATION FOR THIS CENTRAL ASIAN CENTER. RECOMMENDATIONS TO ASSIST AIT BECOME SUCH AN AUTHORITATIVE INFORMATION CENTER ARE TO: 1.REPLACE AIT'S OUTDATED IBM 1130 WITH A CDC 3600 COMPUTER AND ADD ANOTHER COMPUTER SYSTEM IN 2 TO 3 YEARS WITH MORE ADVANCED,CAPABILITIES SUCH AS A 70/72 COMPUTER; 2. SUPPLY THE COMPUTER CENTER WITH FUNDS UNTIL IT CAN SUPPORTITSELF; 3.ADD AN AREA EXPERT-FACULTY; AND 4.RESERVE SCHOLARSHIPS FOR STUDENTS WITH EXTRAORDINARY CAPABILITY.

Title: REPORT : A PROPOSAL FOR CONTINUING ASSISTANCE TO THE ASIAN INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY FROM THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

Abstract: Evaluates performance of Agricultural Sector Loan 514-L-064 in Colombia from 1971 to 1972.  Funds were made available to 5 agr implementing agencies to grant loans which would improve Colombia's agricultural development. Evaluation methodology is based on quarterly reports, data provided by the Ministry of Finance, other sector agencies, and on-site visits.  This summary, the first of 2 parts, covers first agricultural implementing agency and general information about loan implementation. Part II (summary #514 016400 1702) summarizes the last 4 agricultural implementing agencies. During 1971 receipts about equalled expenditures, and exports increased by 22.2%. The major problems to the financial side in 1972 were irregularity in official fund flow during the early part of the year.  Funds were only partly compensated for by Agency short term borrowing from banks or suppliers. During 1972 119 kilometers of the proposed 423.5 kilometers of road were completed under the newly organized pick and shovel access road program along with labor-intensive techniques work on 40 farm-to-market roads which provided employment for 4,000 persons, and extension services were provided to road construction areas to assist farmers use their earnings in improving farm production. In early 1973 the Agrarian Reform Law was modified to speed up the legal processes involved in land distribution and acquisition, to protect the ownership of adequately exploited land, and create a presumption land tax.  The Agricultural and livestock Finance Fund was also modified to enable the Monetary Board to better regulate funds available for loans on long-term crops and livestock, and set aside assets to small farmers including technical assistance. The Natural Resource Institute (IDERENA), one of 5 agricultural implementing agencies, either fulfilled or exceeded its programmed targets.  IDERENA successfully completed:  1) hectare inventories, 2) plot and species investigations, 3) forestry training, 4) fishery management and/or research, 5) watershed surveys, 6) pollution studies, 7) wildlife and national park studies, and 8) ranger training.

Title: SUMMARY OF CY1971 IMPLEMENTATION OF AGRICULTURE SECTOR LOAN 514-L-064

Abstract: Evaluates Lake Shore Road (LSR) Project from 4/68 to 5/73 in Malawi. Proj purpose was to construct a 126-mile road.  Evaluatn is based on on-site observatns, econ data & interviews. Evaluator feels LSR proj was successful despite the tremendous effort involved.  Equipmt was well utilized & may be beneficial in future projs.  The benefits of on-the-job trng will not noticeably affect Govt of Malawi (GOM)'s future econ but should benefit those individuals trained. Road was uniquely constructed under a Modified Force Account Program (MFAP) in which labor, some materials & equipmt were provided by GOM with assist from TEER, a US constructn mgmt firm (CMF) & an independent US architect/engineer consultant.  Initial progress was slow since US constructn equipmt did not arrive until after the rainy season. The main proj prob was the extensive mgmt/admin burden placed on AID, TEER, GOM & TAMS with offset low constructn costs & on-the-job trng. The use of an independent contractor was rejected by GOM since it appeared 18% more expensive than the estimated MFAP.  The MFAP costs were however only 6% over the contractor's bid.  Unlike the MFAP sys, independent contractors are an advantage since they provide for the assessmt of liquidated damages for failure to complet work on time. Contracts give financial incentives to keep constructn costs down, make AID loan reimbursemt eligibility easy to determie and need not train men who will not remain on their payroll.  Consultant likewise judges that even conscientious CMF's will not always see the work is done properly. Disadvantages of unsatisfactory cooperatn between 2 firms & need for more on-site US employees during constructn caused evaluator to recommend that in similar projs only one contractor be utilized. In view of limited benefits other than possible cost savings, difficult admin probs, inherent large scale force account constructn managed by a US CMF & high risk of much poorer CMF performance than that experienced on the LSR, evaluator recommends AID not engage in similar projs unless certain host country wants that method & is capable of doing its part.
Descriptors_Topical: Road construction|Beneficiary count|Limited data

Title: EVALUATION OF FORCE ACCOUNT CONSTRUCTION OF LAKE SHORE ROAD (4/16/73-5/15/73)

Abstract: EVALUATES PERFORMANCE OF NORTH CAROLINA STATE UNIV ON A PROJECT TO DEVELOP COMPETENCE IN THE EVALUATN OF SOIL FERTILITY  PROBLEMS THROUGH SOIL ANALYSIS AND FERTILITY TRIALS,FROM 6/1/63 TO 2/26/73. EVALUATION CONDUCTED THROUGH ONSITE VISITS CONCLUDES THAT THE PROJECT IS FULFILLING ITS OBJECTIVES IN A HIGHLY SATISFACTORY MANNER. IT IS NOTED THAT THE CONTRACTOR'S STAFF HAS WORKED EFFECTIVELY TO DEVISE PRECISE AND SIMPLE ANALYTICAL PROCEDURES TO DETERMINE THE NUTRIENT STATUS OF SOILS. THE CONTRACTOR ALSO SUCCESSFULLY COOPERATED WITH LOCAL PERSONNEL IN ALL TEST COUNTRIES IN CARRYING OUT FIELD AND GREENHOUSE CORRELATION STUDIES. IN ADDITION, THE CONTRACTOR WAS SUCCESSFUL IN THE DESIGN, ORGANIZATION,AND ESTABLISHMENT OF LABORATORIES IN ALL THE COOPERATING COUNTRIES, AND IN THE TRAINING OF LOCAL PERSONNEL TO OPERATE THEM. CONTRACTOR HAS WORKED EFFECTIVELY WITH LOCAL EXTENSION AND DEVELOPMENT ORGANIZATIONS IN THE FORMULATION AND IMPLEMENTATION OF CAMPAIGNS TO INDUCE FARMERS TO FERTILIZE CORRECTLY. SUCH OPERATIONS ARE NOW IN PROGRESS IN GUATEMALA, EL SALVADOR, COSTA RICA AND ECUADOR. LASTLY, THE CONTRACTOR HAS ACCUMULATED AND ORGANIZED DATA AND INFORMATION RELATIVE TO THE AVAILABILITY AND UTILIZATION OF FERTILIZER AND SOIL AMENDMENTS. IT IS RECOMMENDED THAT THE COOPERATING COUNTRIES BE REGROUPED BASED UPON THE FORMATION OF NEW REGIONS AS WELL AS UPON TECHNICAL AND LOGICAL CONSIDERATIONS. REGROUPING WOULD CONSIST OF 1) GUATEMALA, HONDURAS, EL SALVADOR, NICARAGUA, COSTA RICA AND PANAMA; 2) ECUADOR, PERU AND BOLIVIA; 3) BRAZIL; 4) PARAGUAY AND URUGUAY; 5) DOMINICAN REPUBLIC, HAITI, WEST INDIES, AND GUYANA. IT IS ALSO RECOMMENDED THAT THE FULL-TIME TECHNICIAN POSITION IN BRAZIL BE ELIMINATED. IN THE FUTURE THAT COUNTRY WOULD BE SERVICED BY TDY VISITS.

Title: REVIEW & EVALUATION OF INTNL SOIL FERTILITY EVAL/IMPROVEMENT

Abstract: Special Team Eval for 1/18/68-10/15/72 period of progress of the Pathfinder Fund (PF) in achieving AID grant objs of extending & providing interim support for family planning (FP) info & services in LDC's.  Using standardized format for eval of 63 subprojs, PF-contracted team gathered data on and evaluated PF subprojs in Costa Rica, Colombia, Peru, Venezuela, Taiwan, Philippines, Indonesia, Senegal, Zaire, Dahomey. In each area served by PF, there are successful clinical programs with adequate facilities, trained personnel, & satisfactory FP acceptance & continuation rates.  Some form of outreach program has been added to most clinic programs. Some clinics have not achieved objs, as characterized by under-utilization or inappropriate usage (wrong population served), due to inadequate proj supervision. In fields of education & communication, PF is providing support for reaching new segments of population, as with workshop meetings for the press to increase news coverage of population problems (Philippines) and recruitment of women's leadership for eventual influence on public policy (Colombia).  Other educ efforts, such as radio spots & trained motivators, are directed at increasing clinic attendance. Evaluators recommend more attention by PF to program eval, tech assistance, and monitoring & review of past successful projs.  Team also recommends that PF provide professional recruiters to locate trainers; that more fellowships be provided, especially for paramed workers.  Bulk procurement of medical kits & oral contraceptives well-documented & controlled in Philippines & Taiwan, are as of greatest demand.  Eval of transfer of PF projs to other means of support not possible, due to short duration of most projs, but evidence of some transfer in Dahomey, Peru, Costa Rica, & Indonesia.  Specific recs made concerning PF's organiz & admin in areas of proj selection methods; proj extension, review & follow-up procedures; determination of viability after PF support ends; procedures for searching out new projs; & techniques to surmount problems of difficult environments. Appendices contain brief summaries of evaluated subprojs.

Abstract: EVALUATES AID ASSIST TO THE EAST-WEST COMMUNICATION INSTITUTE(EWCI) TO STRENGTHEN EWIC'S CAPABILITY TO SERVE AS AN INFORMATION, EDUC & COMMUNICATION (IEC) RESOURCE FOR POPULATION PROGS-PRIMARILY IN ASIA. PROJ CONSISTED OF AN INSTITUTION-BLDG GRANT (6/22/71) & A CONTRACT (INVENTORY & ANALYSIS - 11/17/70), SPECIFICALLY FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF AN INFO SERVICE LINKING INSTITUTIONS THROUGHOUT ASIA & THE WORLD. BOTH THE GRANT & CONTRACT EXPIRE 6/30/74. A 5-MAN TEAM CONDUCTED A 2-WK ON-SITE EVAL OF EWCI. A MAJOR PROBLEM WAS THE SUCCESSION OF EWC DIRECTORS -- 3 IN LESS THAN 3 YRS. ALSO,THE SALARY STRUCTURE WAS LOW & THE INSTITUTE WAS NOT PROVIDED WITH ADEQUATE PHYSICAL SPACE TO DO ITS JOB PROPERLY. (EWCI STAFF ARE HOUSED IN DORMITORIES & TOILET ROOMS ARE USED TO STORE FILES.) EVALUATORS NOTE THAT THE FAILURE TO SOLVE THIS PROBLEM COULD JEOPARDIZE FUTURE FUNDING. DESPITE THESE PROBLEMS,IEC COURSES,UNAVAILABLE ELSEWHERE,WERE CONDUCTED AT EWCI; THE FLOW OF IEC MATERIALS GREW AT AN UNEXPECTED PACE,AND IMPORTANT WORKSHOPS IN POP,EDUC,COMMERCIAL RESOURCES & COMMUNICATION WERE CONDUCTED. 96 LDC PROFESSIONALS FROM 26 COUNTRIES HAVE THUS FAR PARTICIPATED. EVAL TEAM TERMED THE LANGUAGE OF THE GRANT AS TOO SPECIFIC--DESIGNATING THE NUMBER OF TRNG ACTIVITIES,PARTICIPANTS & THE LENGTH OF ACTIVITIES. THE EVALUATORS CONCLUDE THAT EWCI HAS THE COMPETENCE TO DETERMINE SUCH FEATURES IN ITS PROG. THE TEAM RECOMMENDS THAT THE SELECTION OF PARTICIPANTS FOR EWCI TRNG PROGS BE DETERMINED BY A FINAL INTERVIEW & NOT FROM CORRESPONDENCE ALONE--AS HAS BEEN THE PRACTICE. EWCI RESRCH SO FAR HAS CENTERED ON CASE STUDIES. FUNDING FOR EXPERIMENTAL RESRCH SHOULD ALSO BE PROVIDED. WITH REGARD TO ITS INFO SERVICES,THE TEAM RECOMMENDS THAT EWCI ISSUE A YRLY DIGEST OF THE BEST OF ITS BI-MONTHLY NEWSLETTERS (CIR 2700). IN ADDITION TO ENGLISH,THE DIGEST SHOULD BE PUBLISHED IN 1 OTHER LANGUAGE. ALSO,EWCI SHOULD EXPLORE THE USE OF MICROFICHE. FINALLY,TEAM RECOMMENDS AN AUDIT--ESP SINCE THE VALUE OF SERVICES RECEIVED BY EWCI FROM UNIV OF HAWAII (IN RETURN FOR PAYMENT OF 20% OVERHEAD FROM CONTRACT FUNDS) IS IN QUESTION. DIRECT FUNDING TO EAST-WEST CTR SHOULD BE CONSIDERED.

Title: EVALUATION OF THE EAST-WEST COMMUNICATION INSTITUTE

Abstract: Evaluates an on-going road project being financed by India in the far Western Hills section of Nepal.  India's support for the 140 km road from Dhangarhi to Dandelhura will terminate at the end of FY 73.  Before approving a loan to His Majesty's Government (HMG) for completion of the project, USAID desired this independent evaluation to properly define the project and the work remaining to be accomplished.  The report reviews present construction status, plans, cost estimates, and HMG technical capabilities.  It also evaluates a proposed 80 km road between Nepalganj and Surkhet, also located in the Western Hills sector of Nepal.  The 7-week evaluation included discussions with Mission and HMG personnel, a review of records, plus air and ground inspection. A reasonable balance between labor intensive and capital intensive construction methods has been achieved on the Western Hills road and a similar approach should be used on the Surkhet project.  The attached listing of recommended construction equipment is, superficially, rather impressive for labor intensive construction.  However, the evaluators point out the following facts which must be taken into account:  (1) 84% of the project is in difficult mountainous terrain; (2) the remoteness of the area causes difficult equipment maintenance problems such that "down time" is quite high, and (3) shipping damage plus transit vandalism and theft combine to greatly prolong the time interval between receipt and placing into service of new equipment (in extreme cases in excess of 1 year). Report recommends various changes in road and bridge construction specifications, and recalculates projected costs. Technical capabilities of HMG are limited by experience rather than by numbers or education.  Additional expatriate assistance is needed in bridge design, equipment utilization, operation and maintenance, and, in the case of the Surkhet Road, engineering geology.

Title: ENGINEERING EVALUATION : WESTERN HILLS HIGHWAY PROJECT, WITH COMMENTS ON NEPALGANJ - SURKHET HIGHWAY (4/9/73-5/20/73)

Abstract: REVIEWS DEVELOPMENT OF THE CENTRAL VETERINARY LABORATORY (CVL) PROJECT NEAR BAMAKO, MALI FROM ITS OPENING IN 1/72 THROUGH 10/73. THE OBJECTIVES OF THE CVL ARE (A) TO PRODUCE VACCINES FOR PROTECTING MALIAN CATTLE AGAINST MAJOR DISEASES AND (B) TO UNDERTAKE APPLIED RESEARCH AND TESTING PROGRAMS TO IMPROVE VACCINE QUALITY AND TO SUPPORT USAID'S MALI LIVESTOCK PROGRAM. PRODUCING VACCINES IS ESPECIALLY IMPORTANT FOR THE CURRENT VACCINATION CAMPAIGN BECAUSE SO MUCH OF THE NATIONAL HERD HAS BEEN WEAKENED BY THE DROUGHT AND IS PARTICULARY SU SCEPTIBLE TO DISEASE AND PARASITES. SINCE BEGINNING OPERATIONS IN 6/72, THE CVL HAS BEEN PLAGUED BY ONE BREAKDOWN AFTER ANOTHER. AT TIMES, AS WHEN THE WATER PUMPS FAILED, THE LABORATORY HAS NOT BEEN ABLE TO FUNCTION AT ALL. CONSEQUENTLY, MALI HAS HAD TO CONTINUE IMPORTING SOME OF ITS VACCINE REQUIREMENTS FROM ABROAD. AT PRESENT, THE LABORATORY IS STILL IN A PRECARIOUS POSITION AS IT FACES THE 1973/74 VACCINATION CAMPAIGN. DELAYS IN THE CONSTRUCTION OF A WELL AND WATER TOWER FOR STAND-BY WATER SUPPLY CAUSE THE CVL TO BE DEPENDENT ON MUNICIPAL WATER AND VULNERABLE TO CUT-OFFS DURING DRY MONTHS. THE SAME APPLIES TO CVL'S SOURCE OF ELECTRICITY SINCE THE CVL STAND-BY GENERATOR IS IN DISREPAIR. OTHER PROBLEMS WHICH COULD INTERFERE WITH MEETING DEMANDS FOR VACCINES ARE THE ABSENCE OF ADEQUATE COLD STORAGE FOR STOCKPILING AND TECHNICAL DIFFICULTIES IN THE PRODUCTION OF RINDERPEST VACCINE. USAID HAS CONTRACTED AN ENGINEERING FIRM TO CORRECT MOST OF THEMAJOR DEFECTS IN DESIGN AND INSTALLATION. THE AUTHOR RECOMMENDS THAT USAID INCREASE ITS INPUTS TO ENABLE THE CVL TO ADDRESS SOME OF ITS LONGER-TERM PROBLEMS, PARTICULARLY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR LABORATORY OPERATIONS AND RESEARCH, FOLLOW-ON COMMODITIES, TRAINING, AND FUNDS FOR LOCAL OPERATING COSTS. SUCH ASSISTANCE COULD TRANSFORM THE CVL FROM AN EMBARASSMENT FOR BOTH COUNTRIES TO A TRULY FUNCTIONAL INSTITUTION IN SUPPORT OF THE MALI LIVESTOCK SECTOR.

Title: NARRATIVE REPORT ON THE MALI CENTRAL VETERINARY LABORATORY PROJECT

Abstract: EVALUATES EXPORT DEVELOPMENT & TOURISM LOAN TO CENTRAL AMERICAN BANK FOR ECONOMIC INTEGRATION (CABEI) FROM 9/70-7/73. LOAN PURPOSE WAS TO STIMULATE EXPORT & TOURISM, INSURE BANK GROWTH, AND STRENGTHEN CENTRAL AMERICAN (CA) INTEGRATN MOVEMT. EVALUATN BASED ON CONSULTATIONS WITH CABEI EXECUTIVES. CABEI HAS ACTIVELY PROMOTED THE EXPORT INDUSTRY,ESTABLISHED IMPROVED POLICIES & STREAMLINED ITS SUB-LOAN AGREEMENT FORM. INCREASED STAFF & MORE LIBERALIZED PROJECT REVIEW REQUIREMTS HAVE ALSO STREAMLINED LOAN APPROVALS & DISBURSEMT PROCEDURES. IMPROVEMTS HAVE BEEN MADE IN INTERAGENCY COORDINATN,SUCH AS RELOCATING FINANCIAL ADMINISTRATN OFFICE IN OPERATN DEPT. A CHIEF OF THE PROMOTN & ECONOMIC RESEARCH DEPT HAS BEEN APPOINTED. LOANS HAVE SUPPORTED RURAL TOURISM,NICKLE MINING,ETC. FURTHER,THE LOAN DISBURSEMT SECTN HAS INCREASED ITS STAFF (3 LAWYERS),CENTRALIZED ITS OPERATNS,APPOINTED A COMMITTEE TO ELIMINATE DISBURSEMT DELAYS & LOCALIZED ITS LOAN RESPONSIBILITIES. UNFORTUNATELY ONLY ABOUT HALF CABEI LOAN HAS BEEN DISBURSED DUE TO INITIAL ADMINISTRATIVE DELAYS,COMPETIVE AID BILATERAL LOANS,FAILURE TO SERVE PRIVATE SECTOR & LACK OF SUPERVISN. EXPANSN OF TOURISM IS GREATLY REDUCED SINCE FUTURE DEVELOPMT IS DEPENDENT ON CONSTRUCTN OF HOTELS/MOTELS IN MAJOR CITIES (ESPECIALLY IN COSTA RICA & GUATEMALA) NOW FORBIDDEN UNDER LOAN LIMITATNS. LOCAL CURRENCY COSTS (ABOUT 55%) ARE NOT PROVIDED BY MANY CABEI LOANS. FURTHER,FEW LOCAL BANKS HAVE MADE EXTENDED USE OF CABEI SINCE EUROPEAN INTEREST RATES ARE LOWER,EXPORT/TOURISM PROJECTS ARE LIMITED & CABEI LACKS ABILITY TO MEET LOCAL BANK NEEDS. TEAM RECOMMENDS A $30 MILLION LOAN BE APPROVED FOR CABEI FUNDING IF LOAN CONDITIONS REQUIRE THAT: 1)FINANCED GOODS & SERVICES BE OF US OR LATIN AMERICAN ORIGIN (EXCEPT CUBA); 2)LOCAL CURRENCY COSTS UP TO $15 MILLION BE MADE AVAILABLE; 3)CABEI SUBMIT PLANS FOR PERIODIC SUB-LOAN AUDITS AND PROCEDURES; 4)ONLY FINANCIALLY AND TECHNICALLY SOUND SUB-PROJECTS BE APPROVED; 5)NONCOMMERCIAL SOURCES BE USED; 6)FINANCES FOR CA COMMON MARKET EXPORTERS BE IMPLEMENTED WITHIN 6 MONTHS; AND 7)CABEI MATCH AID FUNDING PLUS SEEK OUTSIDE SOURCES OF CREDIT.

Abstract: EVALUATES CONTRACT WITH THE EAST-WEST CENTER POPULATION INSTITUTE (EWCPI) TO ESTABLISH POPULATION RESEARCH, TRAINING, AND GRADUATE STUDY TO SERVE THE ASIA/PACIFIC REGION. EVALUATION COVERS THE PERIOD 6/1/68 TO 6/1/73. CONTRACT OBJECTIVES WERE ACHIEVED WITHIN THE TIME-FRAME CONTEMPLATED BY AID AND THE EAST-WEST CENTER. EWCPI PROVIDES SCHOLARSHIPS TO 50 STUDENTS A YEAR.  THE EVALUATORS NOTE THAT THEY HAD NO BASIS FOR EVALUATING THE BASIC QUALITY OF THE COURSES AT EWCPI. WHILE AS YET UNSYSTEMATIC, EWCPI DID ATTEMPT TO RELATE RESEARCH TO FIELD PROBLEMS. OF 31 RESEARCH STUDIES IN 1972, 19 WERE CONCERNED WITH COUNTRY-SPECIFIC PROBLEMS -- AND ONLY 8 OF THESE WERE PRIMARILY CONCENTRATED IN LDC'S. THE REMAINDER FOCUSES ON POPULATION PROBLEMS IN DEVELOPED COUNTRIES SUCH AS THE US OR JAPAN. EWCPI'S MOST AMBITIOUS PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM CONSISTED OF 4 WEEKS OF INTENSIVE STUDY IN SUCH AREAS AS ECONOMIC ASPECTS OF POPULATION GROWTH, EVALUATION OF FAMILY PLANNING, BASIC MEASURES OF FERTILITY, AND METHODS OF CONTRACEPTION. THE FIRST SEMINAR COVERED 39 TOPICS, TAUGHT BY A STAFF OF 14(FROM 10 DIFFERENT US INSTITUTIONS). EWCPI'S STAFF OF COMPUTER PROGRAMMERS WAS EXPERIENCED AND KNOWLEDGEABLE ABOUT DEMOGRAPHIC METHODS AND THE COMPUTER FIELD. OVERALL, THE STAFF WAS EFFECTIVE AND WELL-TRAINED, AND THE INSTITUTE WAS GIVEN HIGH MARKS FOR ITS EFFICIENT AND SKILLFUL ADMINISTRATION. COORDINATION WITH AID WAS LESS THAN SATISFACTORY. TEAM RECOMMENDED THAT PROCEDURES BE ESTABLISHED FOR REVIEW AND EVALUATION OF RESEARCH PROJECT FINDINGS AND THE EWCPI PROGRAM IN GENERAL.

Title: EVALUATION OF THE POPULATION INSTITUTE EAST-WEST CENTER UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII, HONOLULU, HAWAII

Abstract: Evaluates project to strengthen family planning programs in developing countries.  Evaluation covers the period 6/30/71-3/30/73 and is based on a review of project documents, interviews with Family Planning International Assistance (FPIA) personnel, and visits to subproject sites. FPIA's performance has been unimpressive.  The management of the central office is weak, with the selection of staff members related more to ethnic, racial, and gender considerations than to qualifications. FPAI's failure to deliver requested supplies and equipment (such as films, projects, books, and pamplets) has resulted in a loss of credibility overseas. Performance in the field has also been weak, with a limited programmatic focus; poor staffing patterns and performance; inadequate planning, coordination, and evaluation; and loose coordination with other FP organizations.  The evaluators note that the FPIA's provision of contraceptives is often redundant, and that the Information, Education, and Communication (IEC) program, which offers the greatest potential for contribution, is particularly slack. Although it was originally planned that FPIA would piggy-back with organizations such as Church World Services (CWS), this has not proven possible -- CWS is weak in many areas and is cutting back on its programs.  Despite these problems, the evaluation team emphasizes that many project objectives have been met.  The Philippine program has been particularly effective.  Recommendations include:  (1) streamlining and redeployment of personnel in the New York office; (2) assigning field representatives to each region; (3) clearly defining FPIA's organizational philosophy and objectives; (4) decentralizing staffing patterns and instituting in-service training programs; (5) shifting away from the channeling of commodities and emphasizing IEC programs; (6) focusing on a few larger projects; (7) identifying consultants with expertise in FPIA's various programs and geographical areas; (8) improving data collection, reporting, and evaluation; and (9) clearly establishing FPIA's role among the dozens of similar FP organizations operating abroad.
